newsitem.title: USA: GM wants to do stock buyback quickly - CFO.
newsitem.headline: GM wants to do stock buyback quickly - CFO.

text.p: General Motors Corp Chief Financial Officer J. Michael Losh said Tuesday the company wants to execute its $2.5 billion stock buyback program quickly.
"We said (it would take) a year in the press release, but we'll report to you periodically, and I think you can look for that program to be front-loaded," Losh told reporters in a conference call.
He said GM's board on Monday decided against a bigger buyback program because it wanted to buy the shares quickly.
A bigger buyback would have stretched out the time frame, he said.
The $2.5 billion repurchase program announced yesterday will allow GM to buy back about five percent of its outstanding $1-2/3 par-value, or automotive, shares.
GM also announced a 25 percent increase in the quarterly dividend on the shares, to $0.50 a share from $0.40.
Some analysts had expected the automaker to announce a bigger return of cash to shareholders, including a dividend hike of $0.20 and a stock buyback of up to $5 billion.
Losh reiterated that GM will consider buying more shares in the future.
"We thought it was more important to do something significant, to do it quickly, and then revisit the subject," he said.
